scope_of_work.problem: DRUPS 1 is due maintenance to ensure the continued performance as per its design. The quality of fuel and fuel tank is unknown to a degree.
scope_of_work.scope:
- Remove all unrecoverable fuel from the tanks, using uplift tanker
- Clean the interior of the tank via manned entry tank cleaning
- Filter the recoverable fuel back into the tank and blend with Enzyme Energy
- Replace desiccant breather
scope_of_work.justification: This work is required to ensure the continued operation of DRUPS 1 to support critical IT load.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: DRUPS 1 may not operate and perform as designed and this could lead to total failure to back up critical IT load

scope_of_work.justification: This top up is required to provide sufficient runtime on DRUPS 4
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: There will be reduced runtime availability on DRUPS 4.

project_name: UPM-UK 2023 Streamlined Energy and Carbon Reporting (SECR) - EIC
status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Brando Dooley DDS

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem:
The Companies (Directors’ Report) and Limited Liability Partnerships (Energy and Carbon Report)
Regulations 2018 came into force on 1 April 2019 and apply to financial years starting on or after 1 April
2019. Kyndryl is required to produce an SECR compliant publication in 2023.
scope_of_work.scope:
CBRE propose to support Kyndryl with the following:
Defining of reporting parameters & processes.
Process mapping, to identifying relevant data.
Portfolio wide activity data and information gathering across Energy efficiency actions and identified savings.
GHG emissions calculations.
scope_of_work.justification:
Kyndryl is required to produce an SECR compliant publication in 2023. The aim of SECR is to further incentivise the improvement of energy efficiency and the reduction of carbon emissions.
Avoid penalties, remain compliant, save energy and money.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Failure to be SECR compliant will make Kyndryl liable for penalties.

status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Flo Hodkiewicz

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem:
FET (Fixed electrical testing) is used to ensure the safety and compliance of electrical installations in accordance with UK health and safety law. It involves the testing and inspection of all electrical wiring and systems between the incoming electrical supply and final circuits 
within a building.  Switchboards, across PH1 & PH1A are coming to our 5 year due date, to undertake our FET testing.
scope_of_work.scope:
Specialist Contractor (Drakeset) will have 2 x Operatives, attend site and in conjunction with 2 CBRE personal carry out FET Testing to PH1 & PH1A Switchboards, (LV8A, LV8B, LV9A, LV9B, RED, YELLOW & BLUE & Package Sub). 
This includes checking main panels, distribution boards, air conditioning and equipment fed up stream, it does not include equipment that 
is plugged in. Testing involves visual inspections and electrical tests on all systems in the building. All circuits should have a - insulation resistance test, a R1 R2 test, A Earth Loop Test & a PFC Test. Circuits shall be identifed and isolated for dead tests to take place, then 
reinstated for live tests. On dual feed equipment and in critical areas we shall follow a FSP, and isolate dual fed circuits so, point of test is safe to do so.
scope_of_work.justification:
Fixed wire testing checks the condition of the electrics against the UK standard for the safety of electrical installations, BS 7671. Each circuit’s cable and accessories is inspected for visual damage and wear and tear, followed by a series of tests to verify the wiring is safe 
and the circuit is wired correctly. Failure to have an up-to-date EICR means you cannot prove you have undertaken the legally required assessment. This means you may be liable for any electrical accident and be at risk of prosecution
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect:
Fixed wire testing checks the condition of the electrics against the UK standard for the safety of electrical installations, BS 7671. Each circuit’s cable and accessories is inspected for visual damage and wear and tear, followed by a series of tests to verify the wiring is safe 
and the circuit is wired correctly. Failure to have an up-to-date EICR means you cannot prove you have undertaken the legally required assessment. This means you may be liable for any electrical accident and be at risk of prosecution

scope_of_work.problem: Twin fan on Cooling Tower 1B, has has the bearings grinding due to them breaking down, the fan runs risk of becoming unbalanced if run and  likely could cause more damage to cooling tower if not repaired
scope_of_work.scope:
Twin fan requires a full strip down on both sections, New shaft, 2 fan propeller bearings bushes and pulleys require replacing on the fan propeller side and then the other section requires a full strip down so the shaft bearings and bushes can be replaced,  ( This is the Centre Section of the set up )
all works will then be tested.
scope_of_work.justification:
The cooling towers help keep Phase 1 of the Data Centre running at the correct levels. If the cooling tower is not operational that will then impact the resilience of phase 1 on site. In warmer months all cooling towers run at full capacity to keep the Data Centre operating 
within the correct guidelines.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Phase 1 of the data centre will lose resilience and could fail when called upon.

project_name: UPM-Phase 1 & Phase 1A Chilled Water Flow Reduction and Rebalance
status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):work in progress by Marge Hills

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem:
In 2022 following on from major changes to the cooling systems at Warwick (new Ph1A chillers, Ph1 single chiller control strategy, IT & Ph2 comfort cooling load reduction etc.) a hydronic exercise was completed to reduce, rebalance and re-test the CHW system

The 2022 hydronic exercise also identified further significant savings can be realised following the removal of IT load from rooms CSE, Hardware 2/Suites 2A & 2B and a modification to Ph1 chiller controls to enable an auto re-start after a “brown out”
scope_of_work.scope:
Offsite
Business Case (Calculated Pump Savings and Project Cost)
Commissioning Scripts for Ph1 and Ph1A primary and secondary CHW systems
Summary report including updated schematic with new CHW flowrates & pump settings and photographic presentation of before and after electrical meter readings 
Onsite
Ph1 A – Hydronic reduction & rebalance to achieve estimated 13% flow reduction in both primary & secondary pumps
Install and test new controls on Ph1 chillers to enable auto-restart following a “brown out” (period of mains voltage reduction)
Ph1 – Hydronic reduction & rebalance to achieve estimated 30% flow reduction in primary & 10% reduction in secondary pumps
Carry out pump tests for both normal operation and failure scenarios on all systems
Simulated building services mains failure test to prove Ph1 chillers

Key dependencies to implement this project:
Removal of IT load in CSE
Removal of IT load Hardware 2 - Suites 2A & 2B
scope_of_work.justification:
There are very attractive savings of:

Annual savings - £153'882/$238'571
ROI - 3.5 months
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: The Warwick site will continue to spend approximately £13k per month more on energy than required.
